Undergraduate Research Assistant Bartels Ultrafast Laboratory/Colorado State University March 2011  –  September 2012  (1 year 7 months) Fort Collins, Colorado Area -Work resulted in a paper in the Journal of the Optical Society of America A and a paper in Optics Letters. 
-Conducted and analyzed experiments associated with SPIFI (Spatially Integrated Chirped Frequency Modulation Imaging), which uses a time-varying mask and a single-element detector to image one-dimensional objects. 
-Theoretically, numerically and experimentally analyzed effects of diffraction, defocus and other aberrations on SPIFI. 
-Worked on extending SPIFI to holographic imaging, two-dimensional imaging, high depth of field imaging, optically sectioned imaging, and other imaging modalities. 
-Used MATLAB and C#. Undergraduate Research Assistant Microwave Systems Laboratory/Colorado State University October 2009  –  February 2011  (1 year 5 months) Fort Collins, Colorado Area -Assisted with design and layout of a small, low-mass, low-power microwave radiometer as a prototype for a next-generation satellite instrument to measure changes in atmospheric water vapor in order to correct an altimeter.  
-Analyzed data from previous radiometers using MATLAB. 
-Used ORCAD and C. 
-Created research group website. Senior Design Project Team Member Optoelectronics Group/Colorado State University 2010  –  2011  (1 year) Summer Undergraduate Research Fellow Jet Propulsion Laboratory June 2010  –  August 2010  (3 months) Greater Los Angeles Area -Improved a high-frequency microwave radiometer testbed, including reducing electromagnetic interference associated with this testbed. 
-Conducted stability testing across temperature and time of high-frequency microwave radiometer internal calibration components. 
-Analyzed testbed data using MATLAB. Graduate Research Assistant Stanford University September 2012  – Present (3 years) Stanford, CA Graduate research assistant in the Stohr and Durr group. Experience Graduate Research Assistant Stanford University High Temperature Gasdynamics Laboratory (Hanson Group) September 2014  – Present (1 year) Stanford, California Graduate Research Assistant University of Wisconsin-Madison Engine Research Center July 2012  –  August 2014  (2 years 2 months) Madison, Wisconsin Research focus:  
 
-	Accurately measuring and predicting the vapor-liquid equilibrium process for the vaporization of gasoline-like biofuels. Although ASTM D86 distillation curves adequately serve as a basis for comparison between fuels, the curves do not accurately describe the temperature-volume relationship observed throughout the vaporization process of a fuel. This research focused on developing a correlation between a measured ASTM D86 distillation curve and the more informative, equilibrium liquid temperature-volume curve. 
 
-	Developing a methodology to theoretically predict and experimentally verify the research octane number (RON) of gasoline-like biofuel blends. Using knock-limited spark advance (KLSA) as a knocking metric, a method was developed to measure the RON and MON of a fuel in a fixed compression ratio, single-cylinder research engine operated in homogeneous fueling mode. Undergraduate Research Assistant Columbia University Combustion and Catalysis Laboratory October 2011  –  May 2012  (8 months) New York, New York Research focus: investigation of the effect of sulfur on landfill gas/syngas combustion emissions and efficiency. Undergraduate Research Assistant Argonne National Laboratory May 2011  –  August 2011  (4 months) Argonne, Illinois Research focus: investigation of the effect of EGR on gasoline-operated diesel combustion. Summary I am currently a graduate student working towards my Ph.D. in physics at Stanford University. I have a passion for designing and implementing experiments to help solve challenging problems and especially tinkering with the resulting data to extract meaningful information. Although I work on fundamental physics problems, I am increasingly intrigued with the vast number of real-world problems that can be answered with today’s escalating amount of data. Please visit my website (in Contact Info) to find out more about my scientific research and side projects studying basketball data. Experience Graduate Research Assistant Stanford University September 2010  – Present (5 years) SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory I use a variety of tabletop and x-ray facility-based ultrafast pump/probe techniques to investigate lattice dynamics in systems with strong electron-phonon and/or phonon-phonon interactions. These include materials with notable structural phase transitions, thermoelectrics, and nanoparticle-laced superlattices. 
 
* Independently managed entire research project studying the fundamental phonon physics of the high-performance thermoelectric material PbTe 
 
* Wrote proposals for, prepared, and directed more than 5 large-scale experiments at 4 major synchrotron / linear accelerator x-ray facilities located domestically and in Japan. In particular, earned experimental time at the highly competitive Linac Coherent Light Source (LCLS) and successfully completed experiment, resulting in two in-progress manuscripts 
 
* Collaborated as a member of interdisciplinary teams in both leadership and supportive roles in over 20 different experimental beamtimes at x-ray facilities, predominantly sorting and evaluating real-time data to make time-critical decisions on the direction of the experiment 
 
* Collected, processed, and analyzed terabytes worth of x-ray data from large area detectors both during and following experimental beamtimes using Python and Matlab 
 
* Modeled and simulated various atomic lattice dynamics to interpret behaviors found in data using Matlab 
 
* Designed and built several tabletop ultrafast pump/probe experimental setups with variable temperature and pressure capabilities 
 
* Programmed and automated a mixture of in-lab processes implementing multiple data collection instruments using Matlab and LabView 
 
* Maintained several ultrafast laser systems Graduate Teaching Assistant Stanford University January 2011  –  December 2014  (4 years) I instructed Stanford undergraduates in both physics laboratory and discussion sections for three quarters. 
 
* Assisted in introductory physics courses teaching “Mechanics and Heat,” “Electricity and Optics,” and “Modern Physics.” 
 
* Communicated challenging and non-intuitive physics concepts to students who had little to no prior exposure to physics. 
 
* In laboratory sections, introduced students to the fundamental approach and mindset behind scientific experiments while they tested the real-world validity of newly learned concepts 
 Undergraduate Research Assistant Columbia University in the City of New York 2007  –  2010  (3 years) I used Raman spectroscopy to experimentally investigate the electronic and structural properties of large area graphene grown by molecular beam deposition. 
 
* Analyzed Raman spectroscopy data on graphene samples using Matlab 
 
* Built and aligned tabletop experimental setup to collect Raman scattered light from samples 
 
* Maintained CW laser system

Summary Interested in physical, analytical, and theoretical chemistry research. This research project focused on the synthesis of asymmetric particles that contain a “smart” polystyrene/PNIPAM core which allows the particles to change in size with temperature variance. The particles are organic-inorganic hybrid with a single gold nanoparticle serving as the irregularity on the particle, formed via one-step Pickering emulsion polymerization. The synthesized particles have applications in targeted drug delivery, catalysis, and solar energy harvesting. Barrett honors thesis encompassed this research.

Member of the Agora Society Undergraduate Research Assistant Langer Laboratory Koch Institute MIT February 2012  –  August 2012  (7 months) I worked directly with my supervisor, Dr. Gillian Hendy on developing synthetic nanopolymers that were both biodegradeable and electrically conductive in the hopes of using these polymers as nerve conduits for damaged peripheral nerves. The ultimate goal of the nerve conduit that we were attempting to develop was to hasten the regeneration of peripheral nerves by providing a scaffold upon which peripheral nerves could grow, and to hasten the growth process through electrical stimulation. I was specifically assigned the task of reading primary literature to investigate prior research regarding discoveries about the body’s response to nerve damage. I learned many new techniques while conducting my UROP. The specific laboratory techniques that I learned were electrospinning, initiating, maintaining, and terminating cell lines, preparing samples for Polymerase Chain Reactions (PCR), running a PCR, high performance liquid chromatography, and scanning electron microscopy. Assistant Coach Joy of the People May 2011  –  August 2011  (4 months) As an assistant coach at JOTP, I was assigned the task of organizing and running 2 to 3 coaching sessions per day (Monday-Friday) for children between the ages of 5-13. In addition, we monitored children, and were in charge of managing equipment needed for coaching sessions.
